1068194618271911936.text: On the left, the conversation around #radicalxchange will need to be about reclaiming the things we count when talking about economics, basically people before profits. Efficiency of opportunity among people, not just efficiency of capital flow.

1068194617667899392.text: On the left, I think one of the challenges will be engaging with the anti-property left, which has become cynical with all numeric representations of value.

1068194616854212609.text: The economist's tendency to ignore initial wealth distribution when evaluating the efficiency of a mechanism seems to be a key here. A poor person can't bid as much as a wealthy person for a plot or storefront, even if they could do something better with it.

1068194616292196352.text: It's maybe bringing ethics to economics, or math to humanities. Its goal is to recover our common ideological heritage at a time of unprecedented polarity.

1068013390159859712.text: Its general thesis in many ways captures the spirit of crypto in a way that doesn't need to discuss crypto at all: We can design more fair social arrangements, period. Crypto is just an extended set of optimizing tools that happen to mesh very well with those goals.

1064023805863972866.text: Anyways, was just sketching an alternative donut chart and then turned into this tweet storm. I mostly hope people at Kialo listen, because I think they're very much on the right track, but I also would love some of my crypto fam to have their minds grace this space.

1064023804597301248.text: Compare to Facebook today, where posting political content is simultaneously the norm and the taboo, a healthier social network would make differences easier to suss out, so that debates aren't endlessly and frustratingly repeated, but instead are nurtured to grow nuance.

1064023803787788288.text: I think this is where it starts becoming more of a personalized discussion, and would simultaneously filter out out-of-network manipulation, but also emphasize addressing schisms between people with a mutual bond.

1064023803045437440.text:
The third step where I'd love to see it go is a fully personalized view, where instead of subcommunities, you just have people you trust to (set of any):
- add new topics
- add new points
- see your opinion (and share it with others)
- curate people whose topics/points you see.

1064023802323992576.text: The other elephant in the room that any blockchain person would highlight is the sybil resistance. Currently it's like reddit if it was all just /r/all. Allowing sub-communities of branded moderation teams would be a good next step.

1064023801543843840.text: I've said before, and I'll say again: I'd like a version of Kialo that allows memes as points. Supporting evidence could still be provided, but memes can be more poignant, digestible, and even fun to go through than text, and is more likely to become a mainstream platform.

1064023800235220992.text: It's up for debate how sophisticated their dataset got, but my concern is partly that their tools for persuading us are outpacing our tools for persuading ourselves. This is completely about how we have conversations online. Today it's mostly meme echo chambers.

1064023799119540224.text: Heck, if you were a total propagandist, and this data set were open, you might say "hey I'm trying to persuade THIS person", and have the computer estimate points from there. This isn't too far from the kind of automated propaganda Cambridge Analytica claimed to make.

1064023797710213120.text: The second element of the GitThought diagram concept is that the comments are represented in a different node from the parent, which allows it to both have its own size and polarity gradient. That size could be the contentiousness, a personalized persuasiveness score, etc.

1064023797068492800.text: But really I want to go deeper: when I'm in a debate, I don't really just want to hear contentious points in general, but actually I'd like to see points that are persuasive to people who held the point it countered.

1064023795487264769.text: If you wanted to just prioritize contentiousness, you might consider a polarity index, maybe something like this:pic.twitter.com/jY2PC7MVSw

1064023794744942593.text: I think having a gradient instead of just an average color is powerful because it helps you instantly distinguish a lukewarm point from a contentious point, which is the kind of thing that is essential to prioritizing when seeking common ground.

1064023794010836994.text: First of all, I want to highlight that each thesis and comment is represented in this gradient pie chart. The slices represent the spectrum of sentiment from strongly agree to disagree.

1064023792190545920.text: Back when I was all about eDeliberation in like 2010 or so, I sketched up another method to visualize, I think it has some benefits, it's not live, so I'll just describe some of the aspects I think are important.pic.twitter.com/jppxtfCXJx

1064023791511072771.text: As a discussion topology, this is a good way to navigate the discussion, because the total width of each slice is wide in proportion to its replies and children's replies (recursively). This is great for seeing all comments represented, but not what comments *matter*.

1064023790273753091.text: I think something as complex as a @KialoHQ debate deserves many ways to visualize and explore, since different participants might think of discussions in different ways. 1060968194079260672.text: Anyways, there's a mini tweet-storm summary from my perspective, since I don't know where to find an up-to-date take elsewhere. Feel free to ask more about a particular area you're curious about.

1060967897093222400.text: Scalability is a huge topic on its own: Individual blockchain sharding, inter-blockchain communication, lighter-blockchain applications are all areas of incredibly active development, and all combine to add orders of magnitude of scalability.

1060967445416951808.text: There's been some nice blossoming of human-centric designs, things that would be cool to build with smart contracts, once all this stuff is working (a lot rallying under the "Radical Markets" banner), but it's of course all somewhat waiting for better scalability to take off.

1060966546611175424.text: The prices are down since last year, which may be helping helping to encourage this kind of foundational development, rather than the manic snake-oil cycle we saw last year, so that's nice.

1060966249314697216.text: The short of it is there's still a really long way to go. Scalability, usability, and even just foundational security guarantees are still all areas of active R&D. People say "where are the dapps?" and I honestly think we're still building the foundation.

1060349642980741120.text: I’m not actively advocating that national voting infra is replaced with blockchains, but I like that the buzzword incites fresh conversations over how we do things.

1060248942896570368.text: I would think this would even play into his desire to eat away at the supposed monarchy of Ethereum, since it could dramatically shift some kinds of power away from the core devs, but whatever. I don't actually have skin in that game, I just want to see efficient governance.

1060248942305136640.text: The key here being that all blockchains, no matter their supposed official governance, are subject to hard forks, hard forks are coordination problems, and therefore if you can simplify the coordination, you make de-facto community governance easier.

1060248941625634816.text: It sounded to me like he'd resigned his chances of rallying a recovery fork, and I think that's too bad. I didn't have any money in that multisig, but the amount of funds at stake seem to me more than enough to merit more effort than was shown here.

1039763371585937408.text: There are still open questions, like "should we list your current counterfactual token balance as your token balance?". Should we show a "real" and "could be" value? Obviously the "simplest" answer is to just show most users the summary. Just tell me what my options are.

1039763369228689409.text: These include things like Plasma exits, state channel exits, withdrawing some counterfactually issued tokens... lots of "exit" things. This matches my earlier intuition that extending capabilities does not require consensus, only reducing them does:https://gist.github.com/danfinlay/73b6ffd11aea5a85767fe20c6ad868c5 …

1039763367253209089.text: In this sense, just like how users have tokens, collectibles, loans, and soon subscriptions, users might also have a series of "optional actions". Transactions that are not meant to be sent right away.

1039763365252542465.text: For each of these capabilities, you might choose to act as if it is at any time, but in general it's cheaper not to, and there might be other implications to activating it. Activation needs to remain a user option.

1039763363172151296.text: At MetaMask, we've been looking at all these different scaling strategies and considering how exactly we might best integrate them, but the family of counterfactual patterns is neat!: Each counterfactual transaction you hold is basically an on-chain capability.

1039763360974286848.text: One thing I like about this is it is a very good minimum viable counterfactual use case. I'll use counterfactual to mean "could be but isn't", and so in that sense state channels are also counterfactual.

1006810882062643203.text: What if you made a one-person counterfactual casper chain? You'd only need the sender to start, you can sign messages to recipients later (with a reference to the previous message, or a nonce), and you could be slashed if you equivocated.

1006810880997314561.text: Get enough signers on that state channel, and you might become pretty confident they won't go back on you.

1006810879428644864.text: While the state channel signers have absolute authority to rescind a permission, the trust model is definitely different when accepting a state channel spending limit. BOTH people would have to betray you, so you might be inclined to divide the odds that either would.

1006809476308045824.text: Just echoes my thought from earlier: Only redactions/withdraws *require* an on-chain transaction in the "capability passing" mechanism.https://twitter.com/danfinlay/status/1006754443419738112 …

1006809195541417985.text: Like the recipients of spending limits usually are, these recipients would be prone to changes in the channel owners' opinions. (ie they can always collude to roll-back the limit, and so they must have authority to rescind the limit at any time)

1006808793643089921.text: For one, a pair of parties in a state channel might agree to grant a spending limit to a third party. That's one basic way those devices compose. And of course, that spending limit could be transitively extended.

1006808485387014144.text:
I wonder if these mechanisms compose at all, or if they're just totally distinct paradigms:
- Locking funds b/c you don't trust someone
- Opening funds up to another person's discretion

1006808484271284224.text: It may not seem like a big deal now, but having to lock up funds just to transact with a single other party could be a pretty big opportunity cost, if the state channel was large enough.

1006808482459389952.text: State Channels are specifically useful when you have a pair of people who *do not* trust each other to not double-spend behind each others' backs. That's why the funds are locked, that's why two signatures are needed, it's a very high security mechanism.

1006808481255616512.text: So, trying to reconcile this with the thinking I've been doing about socially trusting spending limits and how it can scale off-chain:https://gist.github.com/danfinlay/73b6ffd11aea5a85767fe20c6ad868c5 …

1006806919884001280.text: Oh, maybe not, thinking through it: It wouldn't be double spend proof unless the state channel required statements signed by the recipient to close...

1006806019215904769.text: If you just created a 1-of-1 counterfactual channel, you could start a state channel without knowing who the other recipients of those locked funds are in advance.

1006805556152107008.text: Is this really a limitation of state channels, though? With projects like Perun (https://www.perun.network/ ), counter-factual state channels can be connected after they've been created, by initializing a sort of channel on top of their other channels.https://twitter.com/sinahab/status/1006693632676712448 …

1006754443419738112.text: Amidst all the posts today about generalized state channels, I just want to point out this concept, where some applications can scale peer to peer with barely any consensus at all. 974793131504709632.text: Bancor lets you back flatly: Always a standing order at X price, but you can also opt into curved models, give out a discount to the people who help you get on your feet, able to realize your coin's full value (education, small business loans, getting out of a medical surprise)..

974793130741415936.text: Having even a very barely backed token lets you at least demonstrate what your current target valuation is.

974791864674000898.text: One great thing about building this on Bancor that I think Circles regularly eschews is the ability to back it by other previously valuable currencies. Being able to post a buy curve against your token may not be *necessary*, but seems like a huge win for adoptability.

974790975871578112.text: Oh, but I'm not saying I'm against a trickle of money! If a person isn't comfortable minting tokens as needed (and who is these days), an automatic token-printer seems like training wheels to get people to just print their own damn money already.

974790401059045376.text: Bonus: When new tokens printed + trusted are related to goals, not just "unique people", suddenly identifying unique people becomes less important than evaluating the credibility of a project. Sure, they might fundraise from multiple groups, but now that doesn't crash everything.

974789814334537728.text: I also still have mixed feelings about the "regular trickle" of money. The trekonomics I imagine doesn't just facilitate a life support system, but enables trusting groups to coordinate in massive ways. Who needs a trickle? Just print for what you need + find ppl to trust it.

934359923353202688.text:
Someone deleted a tweet asking if this is similar to WeTrust.
Their TLCs are a smart contract for a loan with terms. It's simply a more opinionated, specific type of loan contract. I don't think they compete or necessarily combine, just meet diff needs.

934358329291300865.text: It’s really hard to sleep after a good epiphany followed by related reads and good discussions. Grateful for engaging followers.

934341091196788736.text: It even works for stupid trivial things, like splitting expenses for a vacation. Members can permit each other a certain discretionary budget, and re-up as needed.

934340850913382400.text: Plus, blind “bundles of assets” is exactly the kind of reckless hedging that caused the financial crisis. I’m talking about enabling personal, informed lending to normal people.

934340571702816769.text: While automated issuance algorithms can allow tradable token-backed-tokens, a web of trust by necessity has to be a more intimately issued thing. You don’t want strangers holding leverage over your accounts.

934340294803259392.text: Coming from a web of trust angle, my top priority is reserving a person’s right to revoke extended trust, which would mean the ability to burn people’s tokens. Good luck trading those on polo.

934339853805686784.text: Since Bancor and Curved Token models both have similar concepts of “backing tokens w/ others”, this probably deserves its own protocol, separating issuance/buyback policy.

934335957926473728.text: I agree maybe too much with Bancor here. Even this small piece is worthy of such serious consideration, but almost instantly it's layered with so much more! Tradeability, hard-coded issuance rules, that is not how I issue trust.

934335112484855808.text: Bancor is definitely thinking about some of the same mechanics from a different perspective, it's great!pic.twitter.com/DRbj0I8Vwf

934316540366692352.text: This passage from @davidgraeber’s “Debt” has been somewhat haunting me, driving some of the suspicions driving this concept.pic.twitter.com/2KCSVivNba

934312202625892352.text: I have a lot of instincts that say “that’s stupid, it’s so simple”, but I also have a growing number of reasons to think it might just work.

934311440495689728.text: The concept is: p2p fractional reserve banking. Fill a smart contract with digital assets, give out tokens backed by those. Anyone can redeem instantly, but if they don’t, liquidity is created. Hence, web of TRUST.

934310879482413056.text: Composable from small, individually deployed smart contracts with lots of participant autonomy. No central point of failure, just a pattern for extending trust.

934310485175934978.text: Allows for n-layer transitive trust, allowing for potentially huge community leverage when trust is strong.

934310173396557824.text: Doesn’t require an ICO, no central person benefits, no guaranteed returns for anyone, but lets intimate trusting communities create financial liquidity on their own terms.

934309597883404289.text: I don’t want to just drop it yet because I want to clearly describe the implications first, otherwise it could easily seem uninteresting.

934308978225319936.text: I’ve been chipping away at a web of trust microlending concept for a while and last night I finally simplified it to the point where it seems stupid and obvious and can’t get much simpler.

934157832806473728.text: As a “side effect”, a git-mergable pattern also means blockchain-scalable. It’s all about the merkle dags. Verifiable, discreet changes.

934139198906408960.text: Today’s git-merge is tomorrow’s governance revision process. Design for that future.

934139020417757184.text: All file formats should be designed to git-merge easily. It’s the language of collaboration.
